questions.text: During the examination of the child at birth, you observe that the umbilical cord of the baby has single umbilical artery. While counselling the parents of the baby, you explain them the importance of USG abdomen in this child, due to the risk of which of the following defects?
questions.solution: • Single umbilical artery has association with renal agenesis. Hence, all babies with single umbilical artery must be scanned with USG abdomen and KUB to diagnose or rule out the same.

choices.text: Blood in IVC has more oxygen saturation than SVC
Pressure in left ventricle is more than right
Brain receives blood with low oxygen saturation than limbs
Heart receives blood with low oxygen saturation than limbs

questions.text: True about fetal circulation
questions.solution:
• Blood in IVC has more saturation than blood in SVC as IVC carries the oxygenated blood of umbilical vein.
  • The left ventricular blood has more oxygen saturation that right ventricular blood because it carries the blood of IVC, while blood in right ventricle is a mixture of blood from IVC and SVC.
  • So, the brain and coronary circulation receive blood with higher saturation (through ascending aorta) than the lower half of body.
  • The pressure in right and left ventricles are equal.

questions.text: A 3-month-old boy arrives in the emergency room with tachypnea and retractions. His mother reports he has nasal congestion, cough, and is not able to feed well. On auscultation, you note fine crackles and an end-expiratory wheeze. His HR is 190, and a 2/6 harsh holosystolic murmur is identified along the left sternal border. CXR shows cardiomegaly and increased pulmonary vascular markings. During venipuncture and IV insertion, he is crying vigorously and has an episode in which he appears slightly dusky. Which medication is indicated?
questions.solution:
• This child is exhibiting congestive heart failure. Based on the accompanying murmur and CXR, the most likely etiology is a large VSD.

Features associated with Left sided cardiac failure are:

Symptoms

  • Failure to thrive
  • Irritability
  • Feeding difficulties
  • Respiratory distress
  • Edema

Signs

  • Coughing and wheezing
  • Tachypnea
  • Basal crepitations
  • Pulmonary edema

Treatment

Decongestive therapy

  • Drugs to reduce preload- Diuretics
  • Drugs to reduce afterload- Vasodilators
  • Drugs to increase contractility- Digoxin

Reducing disease progression

  • ACE inhibitors- Enalapril
  • ARB- Losartan

For empirical management of CCF

  • Diuretics are drug of choice
  • Enalapril

questions.text: Statistically, which of the following congenital cardiac defect is the most common?
questions.solution:
• Most common cardiac anomaly- Bicuspid aortic valve
  • Most common congenital cardiac defect- Ventricular septal defect
  • Most common cyanotic heart defect- Tetralogy of Fallot
  • Most common acyanotic heart defect- Ventricular septal defect

questions.text: Which one of these syndromes is associated with total anomalous pulmonary venous return?
questions.solution:
• Turner’s syndrome is associated with coarctation of the aorta.
  • 49XXXXY and 49XXXXX are associated with patent ductus arteriosus.
  • Holt-Oram syndrome is associated with ASD.
  • Ellis-van Creveld syndrome is associated with ASD, PDA, hypoplastic left heart syndrome, TAPVD and TGA.

questions.text: A 2-week-old infant presents with tachypnea, poor perfusion, gallop rhythm, diminished pulses, and hepatomegaly. Arterial blood gas shows metabolic acidosis. Echocardiography reveals critical aortic stenosis. Of the following, the intervention MOST likely to stabilize the infant's condition is:
questions.solution:
• Critical aortic stenosis is a duct dependent lesion. The perfusion is maintained by shunting of blood from pulmonary trunk to descending aorta through ductus arteriosus.
  • Hence, with closure of duct, the post ductal perfusion is compromised and results into shock, low volume pulse.
  • Definitive treatment is surgical correction of aortic stenosis. But as a rescue modality to maintain the perfusion, duct must be kept open using PGE1 analogue- Alprostadil.

choices.text: Ventricular septal defect with pulmonary arterial hypertension.

questions.text: A young female presents with history of dyspnea on exertion. On examination, she has wide, fixed split S2, with ejection systolic murmur in left second intercostal space. Her ECG shows left axis deviation. The most probable diagnosis is
questions.solution:
• Wide fixed splitting S2, in association with ejection systolic murmur in pulmonary area suggests the diagnosis of Atrial septal defect. There may be associated mid diastolic murmur in tricuspid area.
  • Ideally with hypertrophy of the right side of the heart, right axis deviation should be present.
  • Ostium primum is an exception where there is left axis deviation on ECG.

choices.text: It may be associated with VSD.
Subaortic stenosis is almost always recognized in infancy.
In aortic stenosis, a bicuspid aortic valve is the most common finding.
Subaortic valvular stenosis is more common in Williams' syndrome.

questions.text: Outflow obstruction from the left ventricle is characterized by the following except:
questions.solution:
• Left cardiac outflow obstruction can present in different ways. Infants presenting in the first 2-3 weeks of life usually have critical aortic valve stenosis, hypoplastic left heart syndrome or coarctation of the aorta. As the PDA duct starts to close, these babies will become very ill, in shock and heart failure. Emergency support is needed, and valvoplasty (which is not always successful) may save the baby's life - but valvotomy is the definitive treatment in this situation. Initial support should be given, and prostaglandin should be considered to keep the duct open, with correction of acidosis and treatment of the heart failure as an emergency measure.
  • Aortic stenosis normally presents and is symptomatic in teenagers with chest pain and not tolerating exercise. It is usually discovered incidentally when the murmur is found during a routine check. It is most commonly associated with bicuspid aortic valve.
  • Subaortic stenosis is rarely recognized in infancy; rather, it is usually found in children of school age and older. The systolic murmur heard at the base of the heart and on echocardiography is usually helpful in diagnosing subaortic valvular stenosis.

choices.text: Maximum intensity at the left lower sternal border.

questions.text: Which one of the following murmur characteristics supports the diagnosis of an innocent murmur?
questions.solution:
• The characteristics of innocent murmur are
    • Medium-pitched, vibratory or "musical,"
    • Relatively short systolic ejection murmur,
    • Heard best along the left lower and midsternal border
    • Has no significant radiation to the apex, base, or back.
    • The intensity of the murmur often changes with respiration and position and may be attenuated in the sitting or prone position.
  • It is heard most frequently in children between 3 and 7 years of age.

choices.text: Transposition of the great arteries (pure TGA)

questions.text: 4-day old infant presents with decreased oral intake and activity. Birth history is unremarkable and he was discharged home on day 2 of his life. On examination, child is cool, mottled, with decreased pulses. No murmur. Which is the most likely congenital heart defect?
questions.solution:
• This infant is in cardiac shock and is presenting due to closure of the ductus arteriosus, which supports the systemic output.
  • In Hypoplastic left heart syndrome, the Mitral valve is atretic, there is hypoplasia of left ventricle, atresia of aortic valve and proximal aorta. Hence, in fetus the circulation is duct dependent. As the duct closes post-natal, the systemic circulation is compromised and hence there is cardiogenic shock, absent pulses and pallor.

Option A: Remember, isolated Tetralogy of Fallot never presents with shock.

Option B: Pure TGA, is a duct dependent lesion, and presents in this age group. But it is associated with severe cyanosis.

Option D: Differential points for Ventricular septal defect, is significant VSD have prominent pan systolic murmur and presents at 6-8 weeks of age.

choices.text: A murmur may not be present at birth.
A continuous machinery-like murmur is characteristic.
A larger defect will have a louder murmur than a small defect.

questions.text: Which of the following statements is true about a ventricular septal defect (VSD)?
questions.solution:
• The murmur of a VSD is due to turbulent blood flow across the defect. When pulmonary vascular resistance is high enough, blood cannot flow from left to right across the defect. Once the pulmonary pressure drops to normal levels, which is typically by 2 to 6 months of age, the murmur becomes audible.
  • The murmur is holosystolic and usually smaller defects create more turbulence which in turn, produces a louder murmur.
  • Only large defects require surgical repair.

questions.text: A full-term infant develops cyanosis, tachypnea, and a sharp drop in oxygen saturation within the first 30 minutes of birth. On examination, she has normal heart sounds, normal liver edge, and oxygen saturation in the low 60s. When placed on continuous positive airway pressure (CPAP) and 100% oxygen, her oxygen saturation remains in the low 70s. A chest X-ray is performed. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
• This patient's clinical findings and "egg on a string" appearance of the heart are characteristics of transposition of the great arteries. In this congenital heart defect, the aorta arises from the right ventricle and the pulmonary artery arises from the left ventricle. This results in deoxygenated venous blood flowing back to the systemic circulation while oxygenated pulmonary venous blood flows back to the lungs.

  • Patients are typically presented with Cyanosis in the 1 day of life, acute management includes prostaglandin E1 or/and a balloon atrial septostomy to expand the ductus arteriosus and facilitate inter-circulatory mixing. Once the patient is stabilized, corrective surgery should be performed as early as possible.

Option C: Patients of Teratology of Fallot presents after 2-4 weeks of life with cyanosis and respiratory distress.

Option D: Hypoplastic left heart patients presents with cardiogenic shock and pallor. Cyanosis is absent or mild.

Option A: Ventricular septal defect is acyanotic disease, hence ruled out.

choices.text: If the pulse oximetry readings on all extremities at 48 hours of life are 100%
If the pulse oximetry readings do not improve after an infusion of prostaglandin E1 is started
If a chest radiograph and electrocardiogram are normal

questions.text: A 30-hour-old term infant has been feeding normally, has a normal physical examination, and her mother is being discharged. The nurse notifies you that the infant's routine pre- and post-ductal pulse oximetry readings are 99% on the right hand and 91% on the right foot. Over the past 4 hours, he has repeated the measurements twice and keeps getting the same result. When can you tell the mother that her infant does not have a congenital heart defect?
questions.solution:
• This infant has evidence of a ductal shunt that should be investigated further because it can signal the presence of a cardiac defect. A post-ductal pulse oximetry measurement obtained from either lower extremity that is less than 3% to 5% lower than the preductal measurement is indicative of a ductal shunt.
  • A normal echocardiogram would indicate that the infant does not have a congenital heart defect.

Option D: A normal chest radiograph, a normal electrocardiogram, and the absence of a ductal shunt do not exclude the presence of a serious congenital cardiac defect; truncus arteriosus is an example.

Option C: Prostaglandin infusion would only improve systemic oxygenation if the infant had a ductus-dependent lesion and was undergoing closure of the ductus arteriosus.

choices.text: Clubbing is usually the first finding of cyanotic congenital heart disease.
Cyanotic congenital heart disease cannot be present unless an infant appears cyanotic.
Infants with cyanotic congenital heart disease may require treatment with diuretics and angiotensin-converting enzyme (ACE) inhibitors.
Emergent surgical repair is the first step in management for all cyanotic heart defects in the neonatal period.

questions.text: Which of the following statements about cyanotic congenital heart disease is true?
questions.solution:
• Pharmacological management usually is the first step in stabilizing the infant presenting with heart failure. Drugs like diuretics are needed to reduce preload, vasodilators to reduce afterload and disease modifiers like ACE inhibitors.
  • The presence of a heart defect may not be apparent until either the ductus closes or the pulmonary vascular resistance falls, leading to heart failure. Clubbing requires months to develop.
  • Surgical intervention is best performed once the infant is stabilized and some defects require palliative procedures before the infant has grown sufficiently to undergo complete repair.

choices.text: A patent ductus arteriosus is required for survival.
A "snowman" appearance on chest radiograph is commonly seen.
Symptoms may not be present until after 2 weeks of life.
Balloon septostomy is the indicated treatment.

questions.text: Which of the following statements about truncus arteriosus is true?
questions.solution:
• Infants with truncus arteriosus may not show symptoms until after 2 weeks of life when the pulmonary vascular resistance drops and creates increased pulmonary blood flow with accompanying symptoms of heart failure.
  • This condition is diagnosed by echocardiography.

Option B: A snowman appearance on chest radiography is found with total anomalous pulmonary venous return (TAPVR).

Option D: Treatment for truncus arteriosus is surgical repair by Rastelli’s procedure.

questions.text: The MOST common cause of syncope in children is
questions.solution:
Neurocardiogenic syncope, also known as vasovagal syncope, is a common type of fainting or temporary loss of consciousness that occurs due to a sudden drop in heart rate and blood pressure. This decrease in circulation reduces blood flow to the brain, leading to fainting. Neurocardiogenic syncope can be triggered by several factors, such as:

  1. Prolonged standing
  2. Extreme emotional stress
  3. Pain
  4. Heat exposure
  5. Physical exertion

KEY TAKEAWAYS: In otherwise healthy children, neurocardiogenic syncope is most common. This entity goes by a number of terms, including vasovagal syncope, neurally mediated syncope, and autonomic syncope.

questions.text: The most common cause of sudden death during competitive exercise is?
questions.solution:
Hypertrophic obstructive cardiomyopathy (HOCM) is a condition where the heart muscle, particularly the left ventricle, becomes abnormally thick. This thickening can obstruct blood flow out of the heart, making it harder for the heart to pump effectively. HOCM is one of the leading causes of sudden cardiac death, especially in young people, including athletes.

Mechanism of Sudden cardiac death in HOCM :

  1. Obstruction of Blood Flow: The thickened heart muscle can partially block or obstruct blood flow out of the left ventricle. This leads to increased strain on the heart, potentially causing irregular heart rhythms.
  2. Arrhythmias: HOCM can lead to life-threatening arrhythmias, such as ventricular tachycardia and ventricular fibrillation. These rapid, chaotic rhythms can disrupt the heart’s ability to pump blood and may lead to sudden cardiac arrest.
  3. Ischemia: The thickened heart muscle may outgrow its blood supply, leading to ischemia (inadequate oxygenation of the muscle tissue). This can further increase the risk of dangerous arrhythmias.
  4. Diastolic Dysfunction: HOCM often leads to diastolic dysfunction, where the heart cannot relax adequately between beats. This further increases the risk of sudden cardiac events.
  5. Physical Exertion: In young athletes, vigorous physical activity can trigger arrhythmias or exacerbate blood flow obstruction, raising the risk of sudden death

Option A: Postoperative congenital heart disease: Incorrect, it presents with arrythmias, heart failure, pulmonary hypertension, infections, developmental and neurological complications etc.

Option C: Aortic valve stenosis. Incorrect, presents with Chest pain, breathlessness, fatigue, dizziness.

Option D: Incorrect, Many people with long QT are asymptomatic, but symptoms can include fainting, palpitations, seizures, or even sudden cardiac death, often triggered by stress, exercise, or loud noises.

questions.text: A 10-year-old patient has a history of arthritis that started in the ankles, moved to the knees, and then shifted to the wrists. On physical examination, there is a fever (40°C) and a friction rub. Echocardiography reveals mitral valve prolapse and left ventricular dysfunction consistent with carditis. The laboratory results show an elevated erythrocyte sedimentation rate. How long before onset of symptoms does the infection associated with this diagnosis typically occur?
questions.solution:
• Acute rheumatic fever presents approximately 3 weeks after a group A Streptococcus infection.
  • Diagnosis of acute rheumatic fever (ARF) is based on the Jones criteria, which require evidence of a group A streptococcal infection and either 2 major criteria or 1 major and 2 minor criteria.
  • Major Jones criteria for ARF are
    • Polyarthritis
    • Carditis
    • Sydenham chorea
    • Subcutaneous nodules
    • Erythema marginatum.
  • Minor Jones criteria for ARF are
    • Fever
    • Arthralgia
    • Prolonged PR interval on electrocardiograph
    • Elevated acute-phase reactants

Key takeaways: The process begins with a streptococcal throat infection (pharyngitis) caused by GAS. Certain strains of this bacteria have proteins (like M proteins) that mimic proteins in human tissues, a phenomenon known as molecular mimicry.

choices.text: Benzathine penicillin 1.2 M IU for 5 years or 18 years of age
Benzathine penicillin 1.2 M IU for 5 years or 21 years of age
Benzathine penicillin 1.2 M IU for 10 years or 21 years of age
Benzathine penicillin 1.2 M IU for 10 years or 40 years of age

questions.text: As a secondary prophylaxis, what is the accepted therapy in a patient of acute rheumatic fever with rheumatic carditis without valve damage?
questions.solution:
Primary prophylaxis of ARF

  • Penicillin G given before 9 days of onset of streptococcal sore throat.

Secondary Prophylaxis

  • Benzathine penicillin 1.2 M IU IM is drug of choice
  • For penicillin allergic- Macrolides or sulfonamides are given

KEY TAKEAWAYS: Duration of secondary prophylaxis

choices.text: A child with tetralogy of fallot with an aortopulmonary shunt
Toddler with transposition of the great arteries following arterial switch operation at age 1week
A child who had a cardiac transplant 4 years ago
An infant with unrepaired total anomalous pulmonary venous connection

questions.text: Of the following patients, who is at highest risk for bacterial endocarditis?
questions.solution:
• Patients with prosthetic material used during palliative or corrective surgery are at the highest risk for bacterial endocarditis. In the current guidelines, patients with aorto-pulmonary shunts continue to be in the small subset of patients for whom antibiotic prophylaxis is recommended.

Other Indications for prophylaxis of infective endocarditis

  • Child with transposition and transplant for the first 6 months following the operation. (Option b, c)
  • The child with unrepaired cardiac defects (option d)

questions.text: Infective endocarditis is most commonly observed with which of the following congenital cardiac defect?
questions.solution:
• Patients with high-velocity blood flow lesions such as Ventricular septal defects and aortic stenosis are at increased risk for infective endocarditis.
  • Prosthetic heart implants and congenital heart defects are at the maximum risk of bacterial cardiac infections.

Option B,C and D : Infective endocarditis (IE) is a rare but serious complication in patients with an atrial septal defect (ASD). While ASD alone typically has a low risk of causing IE compared to defects with high-pressure, turbulent blood flow, such as ventricular septal defects (VSDs)

choices.text: It is associated with maternal anti-Ku autoantibodies
The majority of patients will require a pacemaker
The risk of mortality is small

questions.text: Which of the following is true about congenital heart block in neonatal lupus erythematosus?
questions.solution:
• It should be considered in pregnant women with systemic lupus erythematosus who are anti-SSA/Ro antibody positive and have previous children with congenital heart block.
  • Congenital complete heart block is the most serious manifestation of NLE.
  • NLE is responsible for 80 to 95 % of all cases of congenital complete heart block diagnosed in utero or in the neonatal period.

KEY TAKEAWAYS: Congenital heart block, is an important manifestation of neonatal lupus erythematosus (NLE) that carries a poor prognosis and high mortality.

  • In severe cases, surgical implantation of a pacemaker, along with the correction of structural abnormalities in the heart, may be necessary.

choices.text: It may be associated with structural heart disease
Has poor prognosis if there is hydrops in utero
Can be treated with neonatal isoprenaline
Should be paced immediately after birth if heart rate is below 60 beats per minute

questions.text: All the following are true statement for congenital heart block diagnosed in fetal life except
questions.solution:
• Congenital heart block is usually present from birth. The baby is usually born with a heart rate of approx. 70 beats per minute but is usually not unwell. Often no treatment is required for many years.
  • However, if the affected child fails to thrive, or collapses, develops heart failure, experiences Stokes-Adams attacks or has a resting heart rate lower than 40 per minute, intervention should be considered.
  • If the child is well and the absolute indications for pacing are not present, then the child should be managed conservatively with 24-hour ECG tapes every few months to document the heart rate. If there are symptoms, or the absolute criteria are satisfied, in-dwelling transvenous pacing should be inserted.

choices.text: Most common cause is post viral infection
There may be family history of sudden unexplained death
It may be associated with mitochondrial disease

questions.text: Which of the following is a true statement for dilated cardiomyopathy?
questions.solution:
• In dilated cardiomyopathy, the contractility reduces. Mortality is via sudden death or cardiogenic shock and echocardiography shows global hypokinetic, dilated heart.
  • Mitochondrial diseases, Friedrich’s ataxia and muscular dystrophies are all associated with cardiomyopathies.

KEY TAKEAWAYS: Dilated cardiomyopathy (DCM) is a condition characterized by the enlargement and weakening of the heart's ventricles, primarily the left ventricle. This dilation impairs the heart's ability to pump blood effectively, leading to reduced cardiac output and, often, heart failure

questions.text: A 14 year old boy presents with episode of unexpected collapse during sports. He recovers within minutes and appears entirely normal. On examination, he is fully conscious and alert. There is no heart murmur but heart rate is 180/min. ECG as shown. Most probable diagnosis is?
questions.solution:
• Delta waves are a slurring of the initial upstroke of QRS complex. The PR interval in this ECG is 80ms. The lower limit of normal in the resting ECG is 100ms. These are typical ECG features of Wolff-Parkinson-White syndrome. It is a disorder of cardiac conduction, one of the pre-excitation syndromes.
  • It is inherited as autosomal dominant and is due to the mutation of PRKAG2 gene on chromosome 7.
  • Many children with WPW syndrome are asymptomatic. The most common presentation are episodes of dizziness, palpitations and breathlessness. Other clinical features include blackouts and fainting episodes. Cardiac arrest and sudden death is rare.

KEY TAKEAWAYS: Wolff-Parkinson-White (WPW) syndrome is a heart condition characterized by an extra electrical pathway (accessory pathway) between the atria and ventricles, which can cause episodes of rapid heart rate (tachycardia). This extra pathway can allow electrical signals to bypass the normal conduction route, leading to re-entrant tachycardia or even more dangerous arrhythmias.
